Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Novel Multijunction Solar Cells for Space and Terrestrial Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this collaborative research project between Arizona State University and Notre Dame University is to explore novel multijunction solar cell designs that offer ultra-high efficiencies for both space and terrestrial applications.

The intellectual merit of the approach is to use lattice-matched II/VI (MgZnCd)(SeTe) and III/V (AlGaAsSb) material systems grown on GaSb to demonstrate the designs with an increased number of junctions to realize breakthroughs in conversion efficiency. Before the device demonstration, very substantial research effort will be focused on the study of the doping in the II/VI (MgZnCd)(SeTe) materials. Various doping sources and methods will be explored. After the successful demonstration of both p- and n-types of doping, p-n junctions and tunnel junctions will be carefully studied before the final integration of them into new device designs. Device testing will be carried out to compare the performance with the theoretical predictions.

The broader impacts of this study include the understanding of the properties of the proposed new material systems and their application to ultrahigh efficiency multijunction solar cells, which can not only reduce the spacecraft launch payload but also enable the terrestrial concentrating photovoltaics systems to minimize the overall wafer demand and cost, from currently 75% down to 10% or less. Since the proposed material systems uniquely offer very broad wavelength coverage, from UV to IR, they can also be used for full-color LEDs, multicolor photodetectors, and other optoelectronic devices. The program will train 1.5 Ph.D. students and reach out to domestic multi-junction solar cell companies and local communities.

Intellectual Merit

            Because most solar cells consist of only one or two semiconductor materials, they can only use a narrow region of the solar spectrum to convert light energy into electricity, thus leaving much of sun’s energy unused. The objective of this project was to develop new types of solar cells aimed at utilizing light from the entire solar spectrum, thus greatly increasing the efficiency of the cells. Our strategy for achieving this was to incorporate into the photovoltaic device a series of different semiconductors that respond to different regions of the solar spectrum, from the near-infrared to the near-ultraviolet. Integrating diverse materials into a single monolithic structure required using semiconductors that (1) have energy gaps corresponding to the various solar wavelengths, and (2) that have crystal structures and atomic spacings compatible with one another, so that they could be grown epitaxially in the form of a series of atomically coherent layers.  

            One strategy for achieving this was to combine semiconductor compounds formed from Group-III and Group-V of the periodic table with compounds formed from Group-II and Group-VI. For example, the III-V semiconducting compound GaSb is structurally compatible with the II-VI compound ZnTe, but the two compounds respond to different regions of the solar spectrum. Using various such combinations, we were then able to fabricated multilayers for multi-junction solar cells that cover the entire solar spectrum. To achieve this we used the method called molecular beam epitaxy (MBE), whereby a crystal film is formed one atomic layer at a time by depositing appropriate atoms on a crystalline substrate. This method enabled us to combine layers of different semiconductor families, and allowed us to fabricate multiple-layered monoilithic structures of very high crystal quality, that cover the entire solar spectrum.

            While fabrication of crystal structures described above is a key component of the project, in order to form so-called p-n junctions that underlie the photovoltaic response of a solar cell, one also needs to “dope” the specific layers with appropriate impurities. One should note here that the II-VI and the III-V materials comprising the multilayers described above require different elements for doping, and identification of optimal strategies to achieve efficient doping was an important undertaking in its own right. Exploration of this issue was carried out in parallel with growth optimization, and we have as a result of this study succeeded in fabricating excellent p-n junctions for multi-junction solar cell operation. As part of this collaborative program, these materials were then sent to Arizona State University for further processing. 

Broader Impacts
